title-group.article-title: Characterization of composite materials damage under quasi-static three-point bending test using wavelet and fuzzy C-means clustering

article-meta.aff: Non-destructive Testing Lab, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Mehdi Ahmadi, Non-destructive Testing Lab, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Amirkabir University of Technology, 424 Hafez Ave, 15914 Tehran, Iran Email: Ahmadin@aut.ac.ir

abstract.p: In this study, two types of specimens, woven [0, 90]s and unidirectional [0]s glass/epoxy composites, were studied. Acoustic emission (AE) monitoring with wavelet-based signal processing technique and Fuzzy C-Means (FCM) clustering method was used to detect the different fracture mechanisms during delamination in quasi-static three-point bending test. The three-point bending test simulates thrust force, the most effective factor in delamination, throughout the process of drilling without backup plate. The obtained AE signals were decomposed into various wavelet levels and classified using FCM. Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) observation was used to determine the different fracture mechanisms. The results show that the energy of AE signals has been concentrated in two significant components for both types of specimens, and the dependency percentage of damages in the two specimens is different.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Among the failure modes of composite materials, commonly encountered in industry, delamination is the most striking one, which may be caused by service life conditions or from production processes such as drilling. With the ever-expanding use of Glass Fiber Reinforced Plastics (GFRP) and the growing fields of its application, the use of different types of machining processes such as turning, drilling, milling, and cutting-off has necessarily increased. Composite materials are combined of two or more materials, which differ in chemical properties and physical shape, in order to obtain the superior properties of all the elements. However, due to the existence of different phases, which causes anisotropic properties, GFRP composites suffer from different kinds of machining problems. Therefore, the mechanism of machining of composites completely differs from that of homogeneous metal removal of conventional materials that have isotropic properties. The existence of glass fibers in GFRP materials makes the machining of these materials difficult. It has been shown that the damage caused by machining of carbon/epoxy laminates led to the reduction of fatigue life and strength of the part. Thus, it requires better understanding of the cutting processes to achieve accuracy and efficiency.1,2

Among the problems caused by drilling, delamination is an important defect in composite materials. Delamination drastically reduces assembly tolerance and strength against fatigue, thus degrading the long-term performance of composites.3 Delamination can initiate on the entrance and exit surfaces of the specimen. Delamination on the exit side of the specimen, commonly referred to as push out delamination, is more widespread and severe. It has been observed that delamination in drilling process has been associated with thrust force, material properties, and so on. Among these parameters, thrust force is the most effective factor during the exit of the drill.4,5

The three-point bending test simulates thrust force due to drilling process without backup plate. Simulation using this method has several advantages compared with other machining tests and modeling using software. This simulation is not complex, expensive nor-time consuming. Because of the specific geometry of the specimens in this study, the three-point bending test simulates the delamination caused by thrust force on the exit side of the specimen (push out delamination) during the drilling process with specific geometry of the tool, regardless of other parameters such as friction, vibration, spindle speed, and so on (see Figure 1). Figure 1.
Three point test and AE device setup. AE: acoustic emission.

In order to identify the main types of damage in composites, namely, transverse failure, fiber failure, and delamination, the acoustic emission (AE) technique is an effective method.6 This event is the result of transient elastic wave propagation generated by a rapid release of energy within a material caused by changes in local strain and stress fields. These elastic waves cover a wide range of frequencies, including audible frequencies, and frequencies in MHz range. Due to noise from the environment, audible frequencies are useless and the applicability of AE is limited to high frequencies.7,8

Several studies were conducted to find the correlation between damage mechanisms and AE parameters.9,10 Until now, most of the researchers have used AE parameters such as amplitude, counts, and energy to study the development of failure mechanisms. Siron et al.11 have applied AE waveform parameters to investigate the correlation between the damage indicators and the physical damage of the composite material. Ramirez-Jimenez et al.12 used the frequency method to classify the failure modes in glass/polypropylene composites. They concluded that the primary event of 100 kHz frequencies were the result of fiber/matrix debonding; between 200 and 300 kHz from fiber pull out and fiber slippage, and higher frequencies emerging in all tests were correlated to fiber breakage. Minak et al.13,14 have used a novel approach, which is called the sentry function, to characterize the behavior of composites during the onset and propagation of damage. They obtained interesting results.

There are several problems when transforming a signal from one domain to another, for instance elimination of useful information. Time–frequency distributions techniques can reduce these problems successfully. Among these techniques, wavelet transform is one of the most proficient methods. Qi and Loutas et al.15,16 employed the wavelet transform for analyzing AE signals through decomposing the signal into different wavelet levels. Each level of the decomposed AE signal within a certain frequency range corresponded to the components. For classifying the dominant fracture mechanism in an order, the energy criteria were used in each level.

Also there are several studies in classifying AE signals using different clustering techniques. Neural Network (NN) is one of these methods applied by different studies.17–20 There are some disadvantages of NN including inconsistent results and long training time.21 Genetic Program (GP) was applied for classifying AE sources by Suresh et al.22 Although GP is a very accurate method, it is a time-consuming process.23 Godine et al.24 utilized integration of Kohonen’s self-organizing map and k-means algorithm for clustering AE signals generated in tensile tests on cross-ply composites. Fuzzy C-Means (FCM) is obtained from adding fuzzy concept to K-Mean method. This technique was used to classify AE signals by different studies.25–27 The obtained results show good performance of this technique in clustering AE events.

This article briefly explains how Fuzzy C-means (FCM) algorithm and Wavelet Packet Transform (WPT) method were applied to provide the relevant information from AE signals to discriminate damage types. The AE signals used for this analysis were measured during quasi-static three-point bending tests. The AE signals of two different specimens were classified using FCM clustering method. Three parameters, which were peak amplitude, count, and average frequency, were used to confirm and validate the FCM-based classification. In wavelet analysis, each level of AE signal, which was decomposed by the wavelet method, were analyzed by the energy criterion. Furthermore, wavelet-based and FCM methods were combined with microscopic observations to validate the results.

sec.title: Materials and specimen manufacturing
sec.p: The experimental work was carried out on the epoxy resin reinforced by the E-glass unidirectional and woven fiber with the density of 1.46 g/cm3, 500 g/m2, and 303 g/m2, respectively. For epoxy the unit of density is g/cm3 and for glass fiber the areal or surface density is considered, for example, g/cm2. Two types of specimens, woven [0, 90]5s and unidirectional [0]10, were prepared for experimental work. The laminates were provided by hand lay-up with compression molding. Rectangular plates of cross glass fiber/epoxy composite plates with blind holes in the center were manufactured in the lab. Also, starter crack was created by inserting a Teflon film with a thickness of ∼20 µm during the molding process as an initial crack for the delamination test. The specimen dimensions were 150 mm × 50 mm × 5 mm. For ease of working, the woven specimen is named A1 and the unidirectional specimen is named A2.

sec.title: Testing machine
sec.p: A properly calibrated universal tensile test machine was used. Specimens were loaded in 0.2 mm/min and 2 mm/min. The load cell capacity of the test machine is 5000 N.

sec.title: AE device
sec.p: The AE software AEWin and a data acquisition system (PAC) PCI-2 with a maximum sampling rate of 40 MHz were used to record AE events. The AE sensor, called PICO, was a broadband, resonant-type, and single-crystal piezoelectric transducer from Physical Acoustics Corporation (PAC). The resonance frequency and the optimum operating range of the sensor were 513.28 kHz and 100–750 kHz, respectively. In order to provide good acoustic coupling between the specimen and the sensor, the surface of the sensor was covered with grease. The signal was detected by the sensor and enhanced by a 2/4/6-AST preamplifier. The gain selector of the preamplifier was set to 40 dB and test sampling rate was 1 MHz and 16 bits of resolution. This sampling rate selection is due to the fact that in composite materials, different failure mechanisms generate AE signals that have frequencies lower than 500 kHz. Prior to the damage test, calibration of the data acquisition system has been done in accordance with a pencil lead break method, for all samples. The pencil lead break operation is based on the generation of repeatable acoustic waves at the specimen surface that are used for the device calibration. During the generation of the waves, velocity and attenuation of the AE waves have been measured concurrently. For the device calibration, the lead breakage procedure was iterated several times and at dissimilar positions between the AE sensors. After the calibration step, AE signal descriptors such as amplitude, rise time, duration, energy, and counts were recorded during the mechanical testing, by two sensors that were placed in a linear configuration located at a distance of 100 mm, as shown in Figure 1. As shown in the Figure 1, the specimens were placed in the testing machine and were subjected to the compression loads through three-point bending test. The applied compression loads vs. displacement is stored digitally.

sec.title: Wavelet
sec.p: New aspects in signal and image processing have been introduced over the last years by Wavelet Transform (WT). Some studies during the last decade represented the WT as a suitable method for analyzing AE signals.28,29 Theory and applications of wavelet transform were noted in previous studies.30–33 In this study, we use discrete wavelet transform.33
Mathematically, discrete wavelet is described as following: (1)

The inverse discrete wavelet transform can be defined as: (2) where f(t) is the signal that should be analyzed, DWT(i,k) are the wavelet transform coefficients given by a two-dimensional matrix, i is the level representing the frequency domain aspects of the signal, k represents the time domain, i and k are integers, and Ψ is called a mother wavelet that is used for the analysis.

Each signal is split into an approximation and a detail using discrete wavelet analysis. (In this study all parts of each level are called component.) The details are the high-frequency components of the signal and the approximations are the low-frequency components. Then, the approximation itself is split into other approximation and detail as shown in Figure 2. Letter L refers to low frequency and letter H refers to high frequency. As shown in Figure 2, wavelet approximations and wavelet details make a tree structure with a variety of levels.32 Figure 2.
Discrete wavelet transform decomposition tree.

DWT is not always useful, because important information is located in higher frequency components, and DWT, applied for the decomposition process of only the approximation component at each level, is not suitable. Therefore, WPT was used in this study. In WPT in addition to approximation components, detail components are decomposed to their detail and approximation components as shown in Figure 3. Figure 3.
Packet wavelet transform tree.

The frequency bandwidth of approximation and detail component is calculated from Equations (3a) and (3b), respectively, where fs is the sampling rate and the number of components are 2i for level i: (3a) (3b)

sec.title: Wavelet-based methodology for AE signals analysis
sec.p: For analyzing the AE signals, the energy criterion was used in this study. This criterion is used as a result of different distribution of energy in each component that is related to the different failure modes.

It is possible to decompose the signal into wavelet components. Equation (4) describes the relation of energy and frequency mathematically: (4) where f(t) is an AE signal and fi 1…fi j are the components of the ith level of the decomposed signal and Ei 1…Ei j express the component energy at level i.
Equation (5) describes the total energy of signal mathematically: (5)
Pi j(t), Calculated from Equation (6), is a relative energy distribution at each level: (6)

sec.title: Fuzzy clustering
sec.p: Clustering is defined as the process of classifying data into groups whose members are similar in some way. Fuzzy clustering methods allow the objects to belong to some other clusters concurrently, with different degrees of membership between 0 and 1.34,35 The data are obtained through the observations of various physical phenomena. Each observation is composed of n measured variables, separated into an n-dimensional column vector. A set of m observations is denoted byP={pr |r=1,2,…,, m} , and is represented as a n × m matrix (Equation 7): (7)
According to membership functions, a partition can be easily shown by the partition matrix U=[γir]c×m. The components of U must satisfy the subsequent conditions: (8a) (8b) (8c)

sec.title: The FCM functional
sec.p: A large family of fuzzy clustering algorithms is derived from minimization of the FCM function, formulated as following (Equation 9):36 (9) (10) (11)

In these equations, J is a fuzzy partition matrix of P, S is a vector of cluster centers, which have to be calculated, D is a squared inner-product distance norm and α∈[1,∞) is a parameter that shows the fuzziness of the resulting clusters. In most practical applications m = 2 is used. The value of the cost function (Equation 9) can be seen as a measure of the total variance of pr from si.

sec.title: The FCM algorithm
sec.p: The minimization of the C-means function in Equation (9) shows a nonlinear optimization problem that can be solved using several techniques, such as iterative minimization, genetic algorithms, or simulated annealing. The most well-known technique is the simple Picard iteration through the first-order conditions for stationary points of Equation (9), known as the FCM algorithm.36 It can be shown that if DirA 2≻0,∀i,rand α≻1then(U,S) may minimize Equation (9) only if (12) and (13)
This solution also meets the remaining constraint Equations (8a) and (8c). Equations (12) and (13) are first-order necessary conditions for stationary points of the function (Equation 9).36

sec.title: Step by step FCM algorithm
sec.p: Given the data set P, the number of clusters 1 < c < m, the weighting exponent α > 1, the termination tolerance ε > 0 and the norm-inducing matrix A are chosen.36 The partition matrix is initialized randomly, such as U(0). The steps below are repeated for l = 1, 2,…
Step 1: Cluster centers (Si) are computed from Equation (13)
Step 2: The distances (D2) are calculated from Equation (11)
Step 3: The partition matrix is updated for 1 ≤ r ≤ m

If DirA > 0 for all i = 1, 2,… c:
otherwise
The FCM iterates until U(l)-U(l-1)≺ɛ.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
During three-point bending tests, various mechanisms control the damage process. Therefore, different regions on AE counts plot can be differentiated (see Figure 4). Figure 4.
Different regions on AE count plot determine fracture mechanisms (specimen A2). AE: acoustic emission.

Region 1: There is no considerable damage in the specimen in this region. There is a stable propagation of delamination during region 1, and the damage level is negligible. These damages do not have considerable affect in drilling tolerances. The obtained data in this region do not have so much effect on delamination damage.

Region 2: When the load reaches a specific level, some strong AE peaks become visible. These relatively high energy signals are probably associated with the initiation and propagation of delamination. This point corresponds with reduction of the slope of load-displacement diagram (Young module reduction).

Region 3: The third region in AE displacement plot is related to the propagation of delamination that causes complete fracture. Due to the occurrence of unstable delamination propagation, AE energies and counts achieve their maximum value in the third region.

Typical raw waveform of AE events in these regions is shown in Figure 5. These events have important roles in the analysis of failure mechanisms. Figure 5.
Typical AE waveform. AE: acoustic emission.

sec.title: Wavelet analysis
sec.p: For the analysis of waveforms, a developed code by the author in MATLAB software was used. In the first stage, to find an approximate range of energy concentration of signals, discrete wavelet transform was used. Then WPT was utilized for the detailed information and applied to every signal. Consequently, wavelet detail components are also further decomposed to obtain its detail and approximation. The frequency range is also split into two equal frequency ranges by dividing the wavelet detail component to its own detail and approximation.

The obtained AE signal is decomposed into three different levels using WPT. In order to ensure that certain decomposition is adequate or more levels are needed the mathematical criteria, called entropy criteria,30 are applied. In this study Daubechies' wavelet family29 was used.

The frequency range increases with increasing the wavelet levels. Each component at level three represents a specific frequency range, and there are eight components at the third level whose frequency range is obtained from Equations (3a) and (3b). Level three of wavelet packet decomposition for specimen A1 is shown in Figure 6. Figure 6.
Three-level packet wavelet decomposition of an AE signal for specimen A1 (amplitude in [mV] vs. samples). AE: acoustic emission.

The frequency content of each component, which was obtained by fast Fourier transform (FFT) method, is shown in Figure 7. Figure 7.
Level 3 FFT of the decomposed components (FFT amplitude [mV2/Hz] vs. frequency [Hz]).

As stated by the Nyquist sampling theorem, the signal must be sampled as twice the highest frequency contained in the signal. In composite materials, different failure mechanisms generate AE signals with frequencies lower than 500 kHz, therefore in this study the sampling frequency was set to 1 MHz. As a result, the frequency interval between the two adjacent components, in accordance with Equations (3a) and (3b), is 62.5 kHz.

For determining the dominant energy levels, all the components of the third level were used. The total energy of the AE signal can be calculated based on Equations (4) and (5). Equation (6) is used to determine the energy percentage of the signal in each component. The energy distribution in each component, are shown in Figures 8 and 9 for specimens A1 and A2. Figure 8.
Energy percentage of each component of Level 3 for A1. (energy [%] vs. samples). Figure 9.
Energy percentage of each component of Level 3 for A2. (energy [%] vs. samples).

The variation of distribution is different for each component. Three components called LHL3, LLH3, and LHH3 have the greatest percentage of the energy. Highest energy for interfaces A1 and A2 are distributed at components LHL3 and LHH3, respectively. Clearly, the energy distribution pattern is different for different specimens at the same component. This difference is the result of different damage mechanisms during the three-point bending test. There are three separate major damage mechanisms in interfaces A1 and A2. The frequency range of three dominant major components is observable from Figure 6. It can be seen that the frequency range for components LHL3, LLH3, and LHH3 are approximately at 100–190 kHz, 200–320 kHz, and 380–430 kHz. The dominant components for A1 are LHL3 and LLH3, whereas LHH3 is dominant for interface A2.

According to previous studies in this field37,38 and based on the above discussion, it can be concluded that component LHL3 at low frequency (100–190 kHz) is related to matrix cracking. The other damage mechanisms, matrix/fiber debonding, can be directly associated to LLH3 where the frequency range is 200–320 kHz. The additional sources in the signal with high frequency (380–430 kHz) are associated with component LHH3 representing fiber breakage failure mechanism.

In specimens A1 and A2, matrix cracking and fiber breakage were more significant events. In specimen A2 about 48% of energy was distributed in the fiber breakage range. This distribution is because of the existence of fiber bridge phenomenon in unidirectional specimens. But in woven specimens, instead of fiber breakage, 42% of energy was distributed in matrix cracking. Debonding was detected for both of interfaces but the portion of energy for matrix cracking and fiber breakage were higher for specimens A1 and A2, respectively.

sec.title: FCM analysis
sec.p:
For FCM analysis, 6000 signals detected from specimen A1 and 10,000 signals detected from A2 during three-point bending test have been selected. Subsequently, the three descriptors including peak amplitude, average frequency, and the counts of the signals were used as FCM parameters. A code was developed for the clustering process in MATLAB and was used to analyze the AE signals. FCM was applied with three clusters. The number of clusters in each data set was determined from the previous section, and the fact that generally within the glass/epoxy composite materials three damage mechanisms, that is, matrix cracking, fiber-matrix debonding and fiber breakage are common. Outcome of the analysis using three classes with different central characteristic are shown in Table 1. Table 1.
Central characteristic of three classes obtained from FCM classification for specimen A1
Signal parameters Average frequency (kHz) Peak amplitude (dB) Count
First class 139.95 49.23 10.18
Second class 265.51 53.47 12.61
Third class 412.20 55.12 11.74

As it is shown in Table 1, matrix cracking, fiber-matrix debonding, and fiber breakage are characterized by classes called first, second, and third cluster signals, respectively. After clustering and identifying the center of the signals, the percentage of dependency of the signals to a special class was obtained as one of the most important output parameter. The results are shown in Table 2. Table 2.
Average dependency percentage of signals for three classes
Experimental condition Dependency on first class Dependency on second class Dependency on third class
Specimen A1 54% 37% 9%
Specimen A2 11% 24% 65%

Regarding Table 2, there is an obvious difference in dependency percentages of signals for different failure mechanisms. These differences are due to different percentages of fracture mechanisms that were caused due to different structures of specimens A1 and A2. In accordance with Table 2, for specimen A1, the first and the second clusters are dominant. For specimen A2, the second and the third clusters are prevalent. Because the data set was labeled, AE parameters distribution could be determined for each cluster. For example, frequency, amplitude, and count of AE signals belonging to different clusters were obtained, and the frequency–amplitude and frequency–count distribution charts are illustrated. Figures 10 and 11 show frequency–amplitude and frequency–count distribution charts, for specimens A1. Figure 10.
Frequency–amplitude distribution charts for specimen A1. Figure 11.
Frequency–count distribution charts for specimen A1.

Figures 10 and 11 show that the distribution of frequency does not overlap, whereas amplitude and count distribution significantly overlap. Dominant frequency range of the clusters is summarized in Table 3. Each range represents a distinct fracture mechanism. Table 3.
Dominant frequency range of clusters for specimen A1
First class Second class Third class
80–200 kHz 210–350 kHz 360–430 kHz

In accordance with the clustering results, there is no obvious difference in count and peak amplitude in different classes. Thus, they are not suitable parameters for analyzing and clustering. But there is considerable difference between average frequencies in these class centers. As a result, and based on the previous section (WPT analysis), it can be concluded that in these tests, matrix cracking and debonding are related to first and second classes, respectively, and their average frequencies are approximately 139.95 kHz and 265.51 kHz, while fiber breakage is related to the third class with an average frequency of 412.20 kHz. The results of the above arguments, FCM, and WPT, are in agreement with the existing researches based on the classification of AE signals related to different failure mechanisms in composite materials. However, there are some differences in the quantitative amount of these frequency ranges. This difference is related to different types of materials, different experimental procedures, different attenuation behavior of various layups, and other conditions of these different studies.

Also, in this study, there were other frequency contents in the analysis, which is not in the frequency range of matrix cracking, fiber-matrix debonding, and fiber breakage. These distributions are related to other types of failure. Different factors may affect failure mechanisms differently. Several factors such as variations in local material properties, localized damage in the specimen, undesired resin between two adjacent layers along the pre-crack region, fiber-rich or resin-rich areas along the propagation direction, may also affect the delamination behavior and cause various failure mechanisms. In this study, this type of distribution was negligible.

Different distribution in the dominant frequency range, for dissimilar failures, can be clarified by the fact that elastic acoustic velocities of relaxation processes and intrinsic frequencies are related to the density and elastic modulus according to Equation (14):39 (14) Where ρi is the density, τi is the relaxation time, and Ei is the elastic modulus.
As a result, the epoxy-matrix cracking creates lower frequency ranges compared with the glass-fiber/matrix interface debonding and the highest frequency ranges will be achieved during fiber breakage.

sec.title: Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) observation
sec.p:
As shown in the Figure 9, matrix cracking and debonding are dominant failure mechanisms in specimen A1, whereas the dominant failure mechanisms in A2 are fiber breakage and debonding. Fiber bridging event in specimen A2 is the major cause of fiber fracture (Figure 12). Figure 12.
SEM observation of dominant failure mechanisms in three point bending test. SEM: SCANNING ELECTRON MICROSCOPY.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this study, after considering the three-point bending test by AE technique, it is desirable to determine the relationship between AE results and damage mechanisms. FCM clustering and WPT techniques were used for the processing of the AE waveforms obtained during the test. SEM observations show that the dominant failure modes such as fiber breakage, debonding, and matrix cracking were the sources of AE signals. But the objective is to determine which frequency range corresponds with these failure modes. For achieving this object, FCM clustering and wavelet-based methods were used.

Dependency percentage of AE signals in FCM and component energy of a decomposed AE signal in Wavelet are comprehensive tools for classifying AE sources. Based on the FCM results, it was found that there are three dominant class centers with average frequency of 139.95 kHz, 265.51 kHz, and 412.20 kHz. Using wavelet analysis, three different dominant components were found at the frequency ranges of 100–190 kHz, 200–320 kHz, and 380–430 kHz. Based on the different visco-elastic relaxation processes, generation of specific frequency range due to different failure mechanisms, these different classes and components are related to matrix cracking, debonding, and fiber breakage failures. Also the dependency percentage and the energy pattern were different from one specimen to another because of different failure mechanisms. Fiber breakage is the dominant fracture mechanisms in unidirectional specimens, whereas matrix cracking is the most significant damage in woven specimens.

As a result, there is good concurrence in the results of FCM and Wavelet analysis. Both of these techniques are useful tools for monitoring and characterizing the failure modes in composite materials.

ack.title: Acknowledgment
ack.p: The authors would like to thank the Department of Mechanical Engineering at Amirkabir University of Technology for providing the facilities for this study.
